title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.7.17-18 | 31-12-2021
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyanati Miran Dasya Gyanan Janishalakaya Chakshurun Meelitam Yena Tasmait Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: Arjuna, who is guided by the infallible Lord as friend and driver thus satisfied the dear lady by such statements Arjuna satisfied Draupadi then he dressed in armor and armed himself with furious weapons and getting into his chariot he set out to follow Ashwatthama the son of his martial teacher
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the context of the verses, focusing on Arjuna's pursuit of Ashwatthama and Krishna's role as an infallible guide, explaining the meaning of 'Achyutaa'.

segments.key_quote: like we the living entities who desire to enjoy materially we give up that spiritual platform on which we are eternally situated in our relationship with Krishna we give up that and we come to the material platform so this is called a a fall a fall down whereas the Supreme Lord and his pure devotees they never fall down even though they come to the material world they are always transcendentally situated
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the concept of 'falling down' from a spiritual platform and contrasts it with the unwavering transcendental position of the Supreme Lord and his devotees.

segments.key_quote: Ashwathama the murderer of the princess seeing from a great distance Arjuna coming at him with great speed fled in his chariot panic-stricken just to save his life as Brahma fled in fear from Shiva.
segments.summary: The speaker continues the narrative, describing Ashwatthama's fear and flight from Arjuna, drawing a comparison to Brahma fleeing from Shiva.

segments.key_quote: Kaha means Brahma who once became elude by his daughter and became a woman and began to follow her This infuriated Shiva Who attacked Brahma with his trident Brahma fled in fear of his life
segments.summary: The speaker explains the reference to Brahma fleeing from Shiva, recounting the story of Brahma's illusion and Shiva's anger, as described in the Puranas.

segments.key_quote: Arkaha refers to the sun god. So there is a reference to this in the Vaman Purana. There was a demon by the name Vidyunmali who was gifted with a glowing golden airplane which traveled to the back of the sun.
segments.summary: The speaker provides an alternative interpretation of the verse, referencing the story of the sun god and the demon Vidyunmali from the Vaman Purana, again highlighting Shiva's anger.

segments.key_quote: when life is in danger they'll do anything to save their themselves or save their life that's natural for any human being but in the course of escaping whether they really be able to save their life that is not assured or that's not guaranteed of course the Bhagavatam advises everyone take shelter of Krishna even Bhagavad Gita also advises take shelter of Krishna
segments.summary: The speaker connects the stories to the present context, emphasizing the natural instinct to save oneself and the importance of taking shelter of Krishna for true protection.

segments.key_quote: proper explains every step there is danger and the safest place for us is the spiritual world the spiritual platform in which there is no danger there is no difficulty there is no death there is no material influence like that
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by reiterating the dangers of the material world and the ultimate safety found in the spiritual world and taking shelter of Krishna.
